title: Judges ordered ICE not to deport these Louisiana detainees. It happened anyway. - NOLA.com
description:
The federal government has deported Louisiana ICE detainees against judges’ orders at least three times since August – and each time, lawyers for the agency have blamed the removals on delays in the system or administrative errors.
In response to the filings, federal Judge James D. Cain, Jr., a Trump appointee in the Western District Court of Louisiana, blocked the man’s removal from Louisiana.
Officials put the man on a removal flight but halted his deportation the day Cain’s order was issued, court records show.
Officials called his deportation an “administrative error” and ultimately returned him to the U.S. following a court order.
Melgar-Salmeron was briefly held in Louisiana ahead of his deportation flight, the Investigative Post, a New York state-based news outlet, reported.
text:
The federal government has deported Louisiana ICE detainees against judges’ orders at least three times since August – and each time, lawyers for the agency have blamed the removals on delays in the system or administrative errors.

The people wrongly deported include a man sent to Haiti nearly a month after a judge ordered the government not to remove him from the country; a man sent to Laos following a similar order that officials said they did not receive until after his plane took off; and a transgender woman taken to Mexico despite a judge’s order blocking her return there because she was at risk of being tortured.

The cases illustrate how, in President Donald Trump’s rush to deport people in record numbers, immigration officials are prone to making mistakes, immigration lawyers say. Those lawyers report seeing removals occur against judges’ orders more frequently; in some cases, they have questioned the administration’s regard for the law.

“Unlawful removals like these, and at this rate, where they're happening constantly across the country, betray an Executive that is completely unconstrained by the law, acting however it wants whenever it wants, with reckless disregard for people's lives and safety,” said Bridget Pranzatelli, an attorney for the National Immigration Project who represents people being detained in Louisiana.

The Department of Homeland Security, which oversees ICE, did not respond to multiple requests for comment but has repeatedly said its deportation campaign is making the country safer by getting criminals out of the U.S. Many recent deportees and detainees, however, do not have criminal records.

Jeremy Jong, a New Orleans-based immigration attorney, said removing people against judges’ orders is happening “more than usual because there’s so much pressure from above to keep on moving people — to move people through the system faster and faster and faster.”

Some advocates also fear that the judiciary’s response to such removals has been too tepid to deter the Trump administration from continuing the practice.

“The government should not simply be allowed to decry inadvertence and escape all consequences for their illegal ‘errors,’” said Nora Ahmed, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Louisiana, which has handled two such cases in the state. “What it shows is that such actions are worthy of nothing more than a slap on the wrist and so they will continue.”

Though it is not a border state, Louisiana is a key cog in Trump’s deportation machine due in part to its large detention capacity: the state has the second-most ICE detainees behind Texas. It also has a holding facility near an airport in Alexandria, which has become a hub for deportation flights.

Louisiana cases

In July, lawyers for a man from Haiti, who was being held in an ICE facility in Pine Prairie, filed a lawsuit arguing the man could not be legally deported or detained because he had temporary protected status.

That status is sometimes granted to immigrants from countries where conditions are unsafe. It allows them to work in the United States without being deported.

In response to the filings, federal Judge James D. Cain, Jr., a Trump appointee in the Western District Court of Louisiana, blocked the man’s removal from Louisiana. Officials put the man on a removal flight but halted his deportation the day Cain’s order was issued, court records show.

One month later, he was deported to Haiti anyway.

Government lawyers said the man’s removal was a mistake, the result of a miscommunication between the Chicago ICE office, which scheduled his removal, and the New Orleans ICE office, which oversaw his deportation flight.

The government said it would return the man to the U.S. after he got a Haitian passport, and Cain declined to hold ICE in contempt of court because he did not believe officials purposely violated his order, he wrote in a Sept. 16 decision.

As of Oct. 6, the man had not been returned to the U.S., his attorneys said in a brief. They did not return multiple requests for comment on the status of the man’s case, and ICE did not say whether he was back in the country.

In the months after the man’s deportation, two other Louisiana cases emerged.

Chanthila Souvannarath was deported to Laos in October after federal Judge Shelly Dick of Louisiana’s Middle District Court, a Barack Obama appointee, issued an order temporarily blocking his removal because of his claim to U.S. citizenship. Officials said they did not learn of the order until several hours after his flight left the country.

Lawyers for Souvannarath, who was initially held in a Lao jail and later released, fought for his return. Dick declined a motion to order him brought back because she found he could fight his case from Laos – still, she said, officials had violated her order, if not intentionally.

Then, in November, the U.S. deported a transgender woman to Mexico even though a judge had blocked her return there after finding she was at risk of being tortured due to her gender identity.

The government said Britania Uriostegui Rios was “inadvertently” removed. Officials allowed her back into the U.S. about a week after she was deported, according to court records.

In court filings, Uriostegui Rios’ lawyers said she briefly went into hiding in Mexico and feared the trip back to the border. When she first made it to a checkpoint, officials turned her away, even after the U.S. had said she would be allowed back in, her lawyers said. She was allowed in the following day, court records show.

A national drama

The Louisiana deportations come as similar cases from across the country make national headlines, sometimes raising questions about whether the administration is intentionally defying the judiciary.

Late last month, a federal judge began a criminal contempt of court investigation after the administration in March left hundreds of Venezuelan migrants in El Salvador despite his order not to.

Attorneys for the government argued they did not violate the judge’s order because his directive to turn the migrants’ flights around in mid-air was verbal and was not included in his written order.

The contempt investigation has been paused after an appeals court temporarily granted the Trump administration’s request to halt the proceedings.

On Dec. 5, a federal judge in Texas called a man’s deportation to Guatemala “blatant lawlessness” because, over a decade beforehand, an immigration judge had blocked the man’s return there. The judge, David Guaderrama, an Obama appointee, ordered the government to bring the man back to the U.S.; officials told Guaderrama the man returned on Dec. 11, according to a Dec. 16 ruling. The man’s attorney declined to comment.

Three other cases have also drawn national attention.

In March, the Trump administration sent Kilmar Abrego Garcia to a prison in El Salvador even though a judge had blocked his return to that country after finding he had a reasonable fear of gang persecution. Officials called his deportation an “administrative error” and ultimately returned him to the U.S. following a court order.

In June, a New York federal appeals court ordered the government to return Jordin Alexander Melgar-Salmeron, who was deported to El Salvador about half an hour after the court canceled his removal order. Melgar-Salmeron was briefly held in Louisiana ahead of his deportation flight, the Investigative Post, a New York state-based news outlet, reported.

And in November, a 19-year-old college student who came to the U.S. at age 8 and was flying home to Texas to surprise her family for Thanksgiving was detained at Boston Logan International Airport. Two days later, Any Lucia Lopez Belloza was deported to Honduras after a judge ordered the government not to move her out of Massachusetts.

name: Litigation
title: Texas AG's lawsuit that sought to shutter Harris County program for undocumented ... - KRGV
authors: ELEANOR KLIBANOFF, THE TEXAS TRIBUNE, www.facebook.com
description:
A Harris County judge on Tuesday rejected Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton’s attempt to shut down a program that allocates county funds to help undocumented people access legal support.
The county, home to Houston, created the Immigrant Legal Services Fund program in 2020 and in October appropriated an additional $1.3 million to keep it going.
Harris County Attorney Christian Menefee said in a statement that this was a “clear defeat” for Paxton.
“Harris County will not be intimidated or pushed around by state officials who are more interested in pandering than governing.” The background: When Harris County started the Immigrant Legal Services Fund in 2020, it was the largest county in the United States without a program aimed at helping undocumented immigrants get legal counsel.
County Judge Lina Hidalgo proposed the program, which passed on a party-line vote.
text:
A Harris County judge on Tuesday rejected Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton’s attempt to shut down a program that allocates county funds to help undocumented people access legal support.

The county, home to Houston, created the Immigrant Legal Services Fund program in 2020 and in October appropriated an additional $1.3 million to keep it going. The program sends funds to five organizations that help people facing deportation get lawyers.

Paxton had called the program “evil and wicked,” as well as unconstitutional. On Tuesday, a judge disagreed, declining to block the program.

The Harris County Jail leads the nation in ICE detainers — a request from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents to hold a person for deportation — as federal and state immigration enforcement has kicked into high gear under President Donald Trump.

Harris County Attorney Christian Menefee said in a statement that this was a “clear defeat” for Paxton.

“The court saw this lawsuit for exactly what it was: a cheap political stunt designed to score headlines,” Menefee said. “Harris County will not be intimidated or pushed around by state officials who are more interested in pandering than governing.”

The background: When Harris County started the Immigrant Legal Services Fund in 2020, it was the largest county in the United States without a program aimed at helping undocumented immigrants get legal counsel. Austin, Dallas and San Antonio already had similar programs.

County Judge Lina Hidalgo proposed the program, which passed on a party-line vote.

“When you have a family at a deportation hearing and they don’t have an attorney, they’re deported at a much higher rate, like 90 percent of the time, compared to like 5 percent of the time when they do have an attorney,” Hidalgo said at the time, according to the Houston Chronicle.

The program sends county dollars to five organizations: BakerRipley, the Galveston-Houston Immigrant Representation Project, Justice for All Immigrants, KIND, Inc. and the Refugee and Immigrant Center for Education and Legal Service.

Why Texas is suing: Paxton argues in the lawsuit that these programs “serve no public purpose and instead constitute unconstitutional grants of public funds to private entities to subsidize individual deportation defenses.”

He asked the judge to stop Harris County from disbursing funds to these organizations immediately, and bar them from doing so in the future.

Paxton has filed similar lawsuits against the cities of Austin and San Antonio over their support of nonprofit organizations that help Texans access abortions. In June, the 15th Court of Appeals ruled in his favor, blocking San Antonio from using the funds the city had allocated to potentially help people who needed to travel out of the state for abortions.

What Harris County says: After Tuesday’s ruling, Menefee accused Paxton of cherry-picking facts about the program and ignoring its “clear public purpose.”

“These are people who live here, work here, pay taxes, and contribute every single day to Harris County,” Menefee, who is in a runoff for the 18th Congressional District, said. “Making sure they can resolve their immigration status strengthens our economy, keeps families together, and makes our community safer.”

In a statement, Menefee and members of the Harris County Commissioners’ Court accused Paxton of using this program to bolster his conservative credentials during a heated primary for U.S. Senate.

“Providing legal support to immigrants who are trying to ‘do it the right way’ was never a concern to the Attorney General’s Office,” Commissioner Adrian Garcia said. “That is, until Ken Paxton decided to run for higher office.”

After the October vote to allocate funding for the legal defense program, Commissioner Rodney Ellis said in a statement that it was necessary because of the increase in immigration raids.

“Having access to legal representation not only improves case outcomes but helps keep families together,” he said in a statement, according to the Houston Chronicle. “In a county as diverse as ours, local government must step up to safeguard safety, justice, and the people we serve."

name: Policy
title: US Senate passes $901bn defence bill | Military News - Al Jazeera
description:
The United States Senate has passed a $901bn bill setting defence policy and spending for the 2026 fiscal year, combining priorities backed by President Donald Trump’s administration with provisions designed to preserve congressional oversight of US military power.
A further $400m per year was approved to manufacture weapons for Ukraine, signalling continued congressional support for Kyiv and cementing Washington’s commitment to Europe’s defence.
Other provisions align more closely with priorities advanced by Trump and Republican lawmakers under the administration’s America First agenda.
The bill also cuts $1.6bn from Pentagon programmes related to climate change.
While the US military has previously identified climate-related risks as a factor affecting bases and operations, the Trump administration and Republican leaders have said defence spending should prioritise immediate military capabilities.
text:
The United States Senate has passed a $901bn bill setting defence policy and spending for the 2026 fiscal year, combining priorities backed by President Donald Trump’s administration with provisions designed to preserve congressional oversight of US military power.

The National Defense Authorisation Act (NDAA) was approved in a 77-20 vote on Wednesday with senators adopting legislation passed by the House of Representatives last month. It now goes to Trump for his signature.

list 2 of 4British Empire: Rule the Waves

list 3 of 4UK PM warns Abramovich ‘clock is ticking’ over Chelsea sale fund

list 4 of 4UK doctors strike over poor pay, lack of jobs

end of list

Several provisions in the bill reflect efforts by Democratic lawmakers, supported by some Republicans, to constrain how quickly the Trump administration may scale back US military commitments in Europe.

The bill requires the Pentagon to maintain at least 76,000 US soldiers in Europe unless NATO allies are consulted and the administration determines that a reduction would be in the US national interest. The US typically stations 80,000 to 100,000 soldiers across the continent. A similar measure prevents reductions in US troop levels in South Korea below 28,500 soldiers.

Congress also reinforced its backing for Ukraine, authorising $800m under the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative with $400m allocated for each of the next two years. A further $400m per year was approved to manufacture weapons for Ukraine, signalling continued congressional support for Kyiv and cementing Washington’s commitment to Europe’s defence.

Asia Pacific focus, congressional oversight

The bill also reflects priorities aligned with the Trump administration’s national security strategy, which places the Asia Pacific at the centre of US foreign policy and describes the region as a key economic and geopolitical battleground.

In line with that approach, the NDAA provides $1bn for the Taiwan Security Cooperation Initiative, aimed at strengthening defence cooperation as the US seeks to counter China’s growing military influence.

The legislation authorises $600m in security assistance for Israel, including funding for joint missile defence programmes, such as the Iron Dome, a measure that has long drawn broad bipartisan support in Congress.

The NDAA increases reporting requirements on US military activity, an area in which Democrats in particular have sought greater oversight.

It directs the Department of Defense to provide Congress with additional information on strikes targeting suspected smuggling and trafficking operations in the Caribbean and the eastern Pacific, adding pressure on Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth to provide lawmakers with video footage of US strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats operating in international waters near Venezuela.

Lawmakers moved to strengthen oversight after a September strike killed two people who had survived an earlier attack on their boat.

Some Democratic lawmakers said they were not briefed in advance on elements of the campaign, prompting calls for clearer reporting requirements.

Sanctions and America First

The legislation repeals the 2003 authorisation for the US invasion of Iraq and the 1991 authorisation for the Gulf War. Supporters from both parties said the repeals reduce the risk of future military action being undertaken without explicit congressional approval.

The bill also permanently lifts US sanctions on Syria imposed during the regime of President Bashar al-Assad after the Trump administration’s earlier decision to temporarily ease restrictions. Supporters argue the move will support Syria’s reconstruction after al-Assad’s removal from power a year ago.

Other provisions align more closely with priorities advanced by Trump and Republican lawmakers under the administration’s America First agenda.

The NDAA eliminates diversity, equity and inclusion offices and training programmes within the Department of Defense, including the role of chief diversity officer. The House Armed Services Committee claims the changes would save about $40m.

The bill also cuts $1.6bn from Pentagon programmes related to climate change. While the US military has previously identified climate-related risks as a factor affecting bases and operations, the Trump administration and Republican leaders have said defence spending should prioritise immediate military capabilities.

name: Litigation
title: USCIT Denies Preliminary Injunction on IEEPA Tariffs – Why Filing Still Matters | JD Supra
description:
The U.S. Court of International Trade (USCIT) has denied a motion for a preliminary injunction seeking to suspend liquidation of entries subject to tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA).
Key Points from the Decision • The court denied the injunction because plaintiffs could not show irreparable harm.
DOJ only promised not to contest the court’s power to order reliquidation of tariff entries—not that it will agree to refunds without litigation.
There is no commitment that the United States will not challenge the right to reliquidation or refund, for example.
Why Filing Still Matters Without a lawsuit, there is currently no mechanism for a court order requiring Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to reliquidate entries or issue refunds.
text:
The U.S. Court of International Trade (USCIT) has denied a motion for a preliminary injunction seeking to suspend liquidation of entries subject to tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). While the court emphasized that it has authority to order reliquidation if tariffs are found unlawful, businesses should understand the limitations of the government’s assurances and why filing a lawsuit remains important if you want to preserve your ability to get a tariff refund.

Key Points from the Decision

• The court denied the injunction because plaintiffs could not show irreparable harm.

• The Department of Justice (DOJ) stated it will not contest the court’s authority to order reliquidation, but this is not a guarantee of DOJ support of issuance of refunds.

• Judicial estoppel may prevent the government from reversing its position later, but this does not create an automatic refund process.

What the Government Actually Promised

The government’s concessions in the court’s recent decision may sound reassuring, but they are limited in scope. DOJ only promised not to contest the court’s power to order reliquidation of tariff entries—not that it will agree to refunds without litigation. There is no commitment that the United States will not challenge the right to reliquidation or refund, for example. Unless the Supreme Court addresses this issue directly or a new procedure is established, filing a lawsuit remains the best way to preserve a claim for tariff relief.

Why Filing Still Matters

Without a lawsuit, there is currently no mechanism for a court order requiring Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to reliquidate entries or issue refunds. While the government could create a new process, it does not exist now. Companies should act promptly—waiting until entries are liquidated or finalized may make the path forward more complex.

title: Minneapolis police chief criticizes ICE tactics after clash with protesters - CNN
description:
Minneapolis’ police chief is criticizing federal immigration agents after a confrontation with protesters and an attempted arrest of a woman in which an officer kneeled on her back as she lay atop a snow bank and then tried to drag her to a car.
After kneeling on her, an agent later dragged the woman by one arm on her back toward a vehicle.
When police arrived, they did not see violence against federal officers and left in an effort to de-escalate the situation, O’Hara said.
The officers sustained multiple injuries including cuts, McLaughlin said in a statement, adding that two people were charged with assaulting federal officers and remain in custody.
Hodan Hassan, a former Minnesota state legislator, said she believes ICE tactics are becoming more harsh as the Minneapolis-St. Paul operation continues.
text:
Minneapolis’ police chief is criticizing federal immigration agents after a confrontation with protesters and an attempted arrest of a woman in which an officer kneeled on her back as she lay atop a snow bank and then tried to drag her to a car.

Tensions have been rising in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area as federal authorities continue an immigration crackdown focused on the region’s Somali community, the largest in the country.

Onlooker video of the confrontation Monday in a Minneapolis neighborhood showed people yelling at Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents to release the woman, claiming she is pregnant and couldn’t breathe. After kneeling on her, an agent later dragged the woman by one arm on her back toward a vehicle.

“Let her go! Let her go!” onlookers yelled as the agent dragged the woman at an intersection close to a Somali business district. The woman was let go.

Police Chief Brian O’Hara told a news conference Tuesday that city police were called to the confrontation by a federal agent who said officers needed help.

When police arrived, they did not see violence against federal officers and left in an effort to de-escalate the situation, O’Hara said. He added that “other law enforcement agencies” may have been using “questionable methods.”

“We have been training our officers for the last five years very, very intensely on de-escalation,” O’Hara said. “But unfortunately that is not, that is often not what we are seeing from other agencies in the city.”

Lauryn Spencer was driving on her lunch break when she heard whistles and honking, which observers have used to warn others of an ICE presence.

She said she approached the scene and began recording immediately, but was shoved back by an officer when she tried asking the woman on the ground what her name was. Spencer said she and others in the crowd were also sprayed with chemical irritants by one of the agents.

“They were being very aggressive from the beginning, like there was never a time where they attempted to use diplomacy,” she said. “I didn’t see anybody throw any hard items. The snowballs were definitely being thrown, but we didn’t start throwing snowballs until they started dragging her around by her wrist.”

Department of Homeland Security assistant secretary Tricia McLaughlin said federal officers were targeting a vehicle when protesters “threw rocks, chunks of ice, assaulted officers and used pepper spray” against the officers. The officers sustained multiple injuries including cuts, McLaughlin said in a statement, adding that two people were charged with assaulting federal officers and remain in custody.

Officers tried to arrest the woman shown in the video because she “rushed an ICE vehicle and attempted to vandalize it,” but the officers abandoned the arrest after being swarmed by protesters, McLaughlin said.

Hodan Hassan, a former Minnesota state legislator, said she believes ICE tactics are becoming more harsh as the Minneapolis-St. Paul operation continues.

“The first week, they were not very aggressive. They were stopping people. Second week, we saw them really aggressive,” she said.

title: Michigan Supreme Court mulls limits on courthouse ICE arrests
description:
Law enforcement would be barred from making civil arrests — including immigration arrests of suspected noncitizens — in state and local courtrooms under a proposal being considered by the Michigan Supreme Court.
The proposed rule change announced last month would prohibit civil arrests of people “attending a court proceeding or having legal business” in any of Michigan’s trial or appellate courthouses.
If adopted, the amendment would add Michigan to the list of states attempting to limit immigration arrests following court proceedings, which have ramped up in recent months as President Donald Trump’s administration cracks down on illegal immigration enforcement.
The court is collecting written public comments on the proposal, which must be submitted by Dec. 22 to be considered.
Court spokesperson John Nevin said the court plans to hold a public hearing before taking action, which “might be as proposed, something different, or nothing at all.”
text:
Law enforcement would be barred from making civil arrests — including immigration arrests of suspected noncitizens — in state and local courtrooms under a proposal being considered by the Michigan Supreme Court.

The proposed rule change announced last month would prohibit civil arrests of people “attending a court proceeding or having legal business” in any of Michigan’s trial or appellate courthouses. The rule as written would not interfere with criminal or court-ordered arrests.

If adopted, the amendment would add Michigan to the list of states attempting to limit immigration arrests following court proceedings, which have ramped up in recent months as President Donald Trump’s administration cracks down on illegal immigration enforcement.

The court is collecting written public comments on the proposal, which must be submitted by Dec. 22 to be considered.

Justice Brian Zahra, the court’s lone Republican nominee, would have declined to publish the proposal for comment, according to the court order announcing the possible change.

Court spokesperson John Nevin said the court plans to hold a public hearing before taking action, which “might be as proposed, something different, or nothing at all.”

title: Congressional Democrats win legal battle with ICE over access to facilities
authors: Stephen Dinan, The Washington Times https:, www.washingtontimes.com
description:

Judge Cobb said ICE’s own internal guidance considers the field offices to be “holding facilities” where migrants are “detained,” even if for short times.
She said the ICE policy therefore violates the Administrative Procedure Act, and she put the policy on hold.

Democrats, furious at what they say is too zealous enforcement of immigration laws, have been attempting to visit ICE facilities in their states to get a handle on what’s going on.
text:
A federal judge ruled Wednesday against ICE’s new policy attempting to limit the ability of members of Congress to carry out oversight on places where migrants are being detained, saying the law gives lawmakers the right of access.

Judge Jia Cobb, a Biden appointee to the court in Washington, said the lawmakers do not have to give seven days’ advance notice before visiting, and can visit both full detention facilities and field offices where migrants are processed and detained for shorter times.

She said a section of the current law that funds Homeland Security Department operations — including U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement — lays out the rules for access, and ICE was breaching that.

Judge Cobb said ICE’s own internal guidance considers the field offices to be “holding facilities” where migrants are “detained,” even if for short times.

And she said the law doesn’t envision a 7-day waiting period.

She said the ICE policy therefore violates the Administrative Procedure Act, and she put the policy on hold.

“All the relevant factors support a grant of preliminary relief,” she wrote.

ICE had argued the seven-day notice didn’t actually prevent access, but rather delayed it. That argument went nowhere with the judge.

Democrats, furious at what they say is too zealous enforcement of immigration laws, have been attempting to visit ICE facilities in their states to get a handle on what’s going on.

Some of those visits had resulted in disagreements and even clashes.

One visit by several members of Congress to a facility in New Jersey resulted in assault charges brought against Rep. LaMonica McIver. She has pleaded not guilty and that case is still pending.

The plaintiffs in the lawsuit were 12 House Democrats.

In a joint statement Wednesday, they hailed the ruling as a “critical victory” for Congress.

“It reinforces the rule of law and reminds the administration that oversight is not optional. Real-time, on-the-ground visits to immigration detention facilities help prevent abuses and ensure transparency,” they said.

name: Policy
title: Judge says Trump can't ban lawmakers, including from MD, from surprise visits to ICE facilities
description:
A federal judge on Wednesday said President Donald Trump‘s administration cannot bar members of Congress from making unannounced visits to immigrant detention facilities.
Cobb blocked the policies DHS adopted in June pending the outcome of a lawsuit by twelve Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives.
Trump, a Republican, has made a crackdown on legal and illegal immigration a centerpiece of his second term.
The Democrats who filed the lawsuit say their unannounced visits, without interference from ICE, remain necessary because detention facilities have often failed to afford basic standards of care.
They said denying such visits amid continued reports of maltreatment, overcrowding and poor sanitation, violates a federal law adopted in 2020 during Trump’s first White House term.
text:
A federal judge on Wednesday said President Donald Trump‘s administration cannot bar members of Congress from making unannounced visits to immigrant detention facilities.

U.S. District Judge Jia Cobb in Washington, D.C., said U.S. Department of Homeland Security policies deeming Immigration and Customs Enforcement field offices “off-limits for congressional oversight” and requiring seven days’ notice for visits violated federal law.

Cobb blocked the policies DHS adopted in June pending the outcome of a lawsuit by twelve Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives.

DHS and the office of House Assistant Minority Leader Joe Neguse, who is leading the lawsuit, did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The representatives who sued come from California, Colorado, Maryland, Mississippi, New York and Texas.

Trump, a Republican, has made a crackdown on legal and illegal immigration a centerpiece of his second term. That has included a mass deportation campaign and the detention of thousands of people awaiting legal proceedings.

The Democrats who filed the lawsuit say their unannounced visits, without interference from ICE, remain necessary because detention facilities have often failed to afford basic standards of care.

They said denying such visits amid continued reports of maltreatment, overcrowding and poor sanitation, violates a federal law adopted in 2020 during Trump’s first White House term.

Cobb, an appointee of Democratic former President Joe Biden, agreed on Wednesday, noting that the law explicitly bars ICE from requiring members of Congress “to provide prior notice of the intent to enter a facility … for the purpose of conducting oversight.”

A number of Democratic elected officials have been arrested for protesting outside of ICE facilities or attempting to enter them.

Representative LaMonica McIver, a Democrat from New Jersey, was charged with assault in May after a scuffle during an unannounced visit to a detention center in Newark. McIver has denied wrongdoing and said her prosecution was politically motivated.

Daniel Wiessner reports for Reuters.

title: Medicaid service providers sue DHS over withholding payments during fraud investigations
description:
As the Walz administration clamps down on fraud in state-run Medicaid programs, service providers are fighting back in court.
In another suit in October, a personal care assistant filed suit and DHS resumed Medicaid payments a week later.
Historically, under the older statute, state and federal courts have not allowed Medicaid program providers the right to appeal payment sanctions.
DHS investigating connections between different providers DHS is also investigating and pausing payments for providers affiliated with other providers suspected of fraud.
The investigation emerged out of the Feeding Our Future investigation; state spending on autism services exploded by 3,000% in recent years.
text:
As the Walz administration clamps down on fraud in state-run Medicaid programs, service providers are fighting back in court.

At least half a dozen providers have sued the state Department of Human Services in recent months over suspended payments, which they say have either shut down their businesses or put them at existential risk, harming the clients who depend on their services.

One lawsuit filed in August in district court was dismissed in early December. In another suit in October, a personal care assistant filed suit and DHS resumed Medicaid payments a week later.

A lawsuit from a provider against DHS from September is ongoing, and three additional lawsuits were filed just last week.

The litigation is yet another fallout from the Walz administration’s focus on rooting out fraud in public programs after years of inaction, beginning with the now-notorious Feeding Our Future case that led to more than 75 federal charges and has since morphed into a wide-ranging Medicaid fraud investigation.

The stakes are significant: Successful litigation could encourage more providers to sue, which would complicate the administration’s efforts to thwart the burgeoning fraud scandal — and with it, Gov. Tim Walz’s 2026 reelection efforts.

Provider lawsuit dismissed by district court

A district court dismissed a lawsuit from Empathy Home Care in August in which the provider alleged that DHS stopped payments for its assisted living services starting in May but offered no evidence of fraud.

Michael Schwartz, Empathy Home Care’s attorney, said that “the state’s response to allegations of widespread fraud is being dealt with by just shutting payments off to a whole blanket of people, including Empathy, who’ve done nothing wrong.”

According to a court memo from the Minnesota Attorney General’s Office, evidence gathered by DHS indicated that Empathy Home Care billed for services that it didn’t provide. The memo also said that DHS had evidence that Medicaid recipients went missing when services were supposed to be provided and overdosed without staff attempting to save them.

Much of Empathy’s legal argument rests on a new section in Minnesota statute that limits payment stoppages from all state agencies to 60 days if there’s evidence of fraud. But an older Minnesota statute, which applies specifically to Medicaid-funded services, allows DHS to impose sanctions on Medicaid providers until “the commissioner determines there is insufficient evidence of fraud by the individual or entity, or after legal proceedings relating to the alleged fraud are completed.”

The Minnesota 4th District Court ruled in early December that the older statute is in force, allowing DHS to continue to withhold payment beyond the 60 days allowed in the new statute. Historically, under the older statute, state and federal courts have not allowed Medicaid program providers the right to appeal payment sanctions.

Schwartz said that Empathy plans to appeal the court’s decision this week.

Integrated Community Supports provider sues

The three providers that filed lawsuits against DHS last week range in what services they provide and why DHS suspended their payments.

Bright Community Services says it helps more than 30 adults through Integrated Community Support services, a program that has been under scrutiny by DHS. The program started in 2021 and is designed to help disabled adults live more independently in apartments rather than in an institution.

Following federal charges against dozens of people alleging they defrauded a child nutrition program, an autism treatment program and Housing Stabilization Services, DHS paused payments for some ICS providers starting in September and implementing a prepayment auditing process this month for 14 programs, including ICS.

DHS has withheld payments to 17 ICS providers as of late November. Bright Community Services was one of them — but, like Empathy Home Care, the business alleges that DHS suspended its payments without explanation. It also said that it asked DHS “on numerous occasions” for further explanation of the fraud allegation but received no response.

Bright Community Services has stopped offering services because it’s now unable to pay staff, according to the lawsuit. DHS has said that providers are still allowed to continue providing services while they stop payments.

“No business can reasonably be expected to do that,” reads the lawsuit from Bright Community Services.

A DHS spokesperson confirmed in a statement that all payments to Bright Community Services were suspended based on “credible allegations of fraud,” which have also been referred to law enforcement. The statement also said that payments may resume if the provider submits sufficient information to demonstrate that there was no fraud.

Lataa Elemo, who operates Bright Community Services, declined an interview request. So far, no providers have faced state or federal charges for defrauding ICS.

DHS investigating connections between different providers

DHS is also investigating and pausing payments for providers affiliated with other providers suspected of fraud.

Two Medicaid program providers partly owned by the same person, Suleiman Isse — Joy Home Healthcare and Hennepin Autism Center — filed a lawsuit against DHS in September over payments halted in June.

DHS said in a notice that it suspended payments to Hennepin Autism in part because it had evidence that the autism center participated in the Feeding Our Future fraud scheme, which the autism center denied. DHS additionally suspended payments to Joy Home Healthcare because of its shared ownership with Hennepin Autism.

A previous Reformer analysis of state records found that a Feeding Our Future defendant, Yusuf Bashir Ali, was an officer of the Hennepin Autism Center in 2020. Ali was removed as an officer two years later — a couple of months after he was charged with wire fraud and money laundering in the Feeding Our Future case.

That lawsuit is ongoing. The attorney representing the providers declined to comment.

Another provider, Agape Home Care Services, received a notice from DHS in September that the business was cut off from payments because of its affiliation with another provider under investigation for fraud, Healthy Living Home Care, according to another recent lawsuit.

Agape doesn’t provide ICS services but does provide other home- and community-based services, as well as nursing services, that are also paid through state-run Medicaid programs.

Michael Hunter, the co-owner of Agape, said that he owns 30% of Healthy Living Home Care but plays no part in the business operations of Healthy Living.

“Because someone has a stake in another company, you put another whole company on payment hold,” Hunter said. “We are not being accused of any wrongdoing, nothing like that.”

Since the payment hold started, Agape has had to stop providing services to all of its clients, Hunter said. The organization usually has 10 to 15 clients, many of whom have intense behavioral and medical needs and were sent to the hospital once services stopped, he said.

Hunter said that Healthy Living Home Care is still waiting to hear why their payments are being withheld. According to Hunter, DHS surveyed Healthy Living but “there was nothing on fraud” in the survey.

DHS and government officials have provided limited information, citing active investigations.

“Hopefully it’s understandable that we don’t want to be too forthcoming about what kinds of actions cause investigators to suspect someone is billing for services they didn’t provide, but in general we look for patterns of concern,” said a DHS spokesperson, in an email.

As in Empathy’s case, Agape’s lawsuit and another lawsuit recently filed by Benevolence LLC, an autism services provider, make the case that DHS can only stop payments for 60 days under the new statute.

A representative from Benevolence LLC declined to comment.

Federal investigators have charged one person for defrauding the autism program. The investigation emerged out of the Feeding Our Future investigation; state spending on autism services exploded by 3,000% in recent years.

Suing the state has been a successful strategy in the past

In yet another lawsuit, a personal care assistant alleged in October that her payments for taking care of her disabled son were suspended two years ago, and that she wasn’t given information or a timeline on DHS’s fraud investigation.

Joseph Dixon, the attorney for the personal care assistant, said that DHS “simply withdrew the payment suspension” rather than respond to the lawsuit, making the case moot.

Feeding Our Future, the nonprofit at the center of a $250 million scheme defrauding the federal government of pandemic money intended to feed children, filed a lawsuit in 2020 against the Minnesota Department of Education when the agency stopped processing applications for new meal sites. Feeding Our Future accused the agency of discriminating on the basis of race, national origin and religion.

Though the judge hearing the case never issued a written order for the Department of Education to resume payments to Feeding Our Future, he did say the state did not have authority to stop payments, according to a transcript of a 2021 hearing reviewed by the Star Tribune. Though stopped payments were outside of the purview of the lawsuit, which centered on meal site applications, MDE resumed payments six days later.

In 2022, MDE said in a statement that “the court made it clear that if MDE were to continue the legal fight to withhold payments, MDE would incur sanctions and legal penalties.”

title: EXCLUSIVE: ICE arrest outside of Pinehurst Elementary sparks backlash; family speaks out
description:
– What seemed like a routine school drop-off quickly turned into something explosive after Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents responded to Pinehurst Avenue on Wednesday morning.
Twenty-four-year-old Vanessa Parazall had just finished dropping her daughter off at Pinehurst Elementary School, when she was suddenly swarmed by ICE agents in unmarked cars.
In a video, captured by Watkins, at least six men, wearing masks and tactical gear, are seen trying to pull Parazall from her vehicle.
Parazall’s sister-in-law, Sophia Livingston, alleges that the father of Parazall’s daughter called ICE on her because of an ongoing custody dispute.
One community member, Olivia Wackett, expressed her shock after attending an event at the school just a week prior.
text:
SALISBURY, Md. – What seemed like a routine school drop-off quickly turned into something explosive after Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents responded to Pinehurst Avenue on Wednesday morning.

Twenty-four-year-old Vanessa Parazall had just finished dropping her daughter off at Pinehurst Elementary School, when she was suddenly swarmed by ICE agents in unmarked cars. Her neighbor, Elizabeth Watkins, was traveling behind her when the confrontation began.

In a video, captured by Watkins, at least six men, wearing masks and tactical gear, are seen trying to pull Parazall from her vehicle. When Watkins questions the officers’ activity, one agent tells her that Parazall “is illegal and she has aggravated charges.” Parazall was ultimately detained by authorities, and her vehicle was damaged in the process.

Parazall’s sister-in-law, Sophia Livingston, alleges that the father of Parazall’s daughter called ICE on her because of an ongoing custody dispute.

“She called me earlier, I could barely understand her from how upset she was. She said, ‘Please protect my child, please protect my family,'” Livingston says. “Her daughter has not seen her dad in over a year [and] her daughter does not want to go with her dad.”

Parents and community members promptly organized a protest outside of the elementary school during pickup hours. One community member, Olivia Wackett, expressed her shock after attending an event at the school just a week prior.

“It’s so jarring to have gone from experiencing that and feeling this true sense of belonging, community, loving and supporting one another to look out of my window and see this car completely bashed in,” Wackett says. “This has a ripple effect; it’s not just the person that was ripped from their car this morning that this has impacted… it’s our entire community it’s our children that are being impacted by this.”

In a statement to WMDT, Wicomico County Public Schools acknowledged this morning’s detainment, stating, “This incident did not take place on school property, and there was no disruption to school operations. In compliance with Wicomico County Board of Education policies, procedures, and applicable legal directives, only individuals legally authorized to access students may initiate any form of contact with a student.”

Parazall remains in ICE custody at this time. Sources tell WMDT she is being transferred to holding location in Baltimore.

title: How Spanish-language community stations are navigating immigration crackdowns
authors: Francisco Rodriguez, Hola Cultura, Francisco is likely reading
description:
Spanish-language and multilingual community radio stations nationwide are adapting how they serve their communities and volunteers in response to the Trump administration’s intensified crackdowns on immigration.
We have to rise to the occasion.” Know your rights The increased presence of federal immigration enforcement agents is a major issue for multiple multilingual community radio stations and their communities, Dael said.
“To be a volunteer at a community radio station, no one asks your status of citizenship or being here legally or illegally.
Numerous stations have adopted and distributed red cards among volunteers, she said.
“We have tens of thousands of our people who don’t have access to real information in real time, and I think community radio stations should play a role.” Perez said community radio stations like KYMZ must continue their indispensable service during uncertain times, as many Spanish-speaking communities depend on stations for news and information.
text:
Spanish-language and multilingual community radio stations nationwide are adapting how they serve their communities and volunteers in response to the Trump administration’s intensified crackdowns on immigration.

Multiple stations have been at the forefront of providing local audiences with up-to-date immigration-related news and information to make sense of the oftentimes armed, masked and plainclothed federal agents forcefully detaining loved ones and other community members.

Amid these enforcement activities, such as the increased presence of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, station staffers say they feel they must walk a line between providing information necessary to navigate new norms without inviting unwanted attention or potential retaliation.

Rima Dael, CEO of the National Federation of Community Broadcasters, said staffers at many of these stations, many of whom are people of color, are feeling anxious as they find the best route forward while the Trump administration attacks and dehumanizes nonwhite people.

“Talking to some stations, some of the conversations are, ‘How can we continue to speak out against the current administration?’” Dael said. “Then, the tension arises of … ‘Let’s de-escalate talking about those issues so there isn’t a target on the station’s back,’ because they want to be a safe haven and refuge for people of marginalized and historically underrepresented identities.”

Radio Bilingüe, the California-based Spanish-language radio network that broadcasts in parts of the U.S. and Mexico, is one of the outlets working to ensure its communities have reliable access to vital information about public health, labor rights and immigration as they face uncertainty under the Trump administration.

Though the network is among the organizations strained by Congress’ rescission of $1.1 billion in CPB funds, Co-Executive Director José Martínez-Saldaña said it remains committed to empowering its communities, no matter the obstacles.

“We are tightening our belt where we can, but we have no plans and no interest in scaling back what we do,” Martínez-Saldaña said. “The information and the content that we provide locally as well as nationally couldn’t be more critical than at this time. We have to rise to the occasion.”

Know your rights

The increased presence of federal immigration enforcement agents is a major issue for multiple multilingual community radio stations and their communities, Dael said.

“These are stations … that might be all volunteer-driven,” Dael said. “To be a volunteer at a community radio station, no one asks your status of citizenship or being here legally or illegally. It’s, ‘Hey, you live in the community? You want to be on the radio? You want to be part of this community hub? Come right in!’”

Dael said numerous stations are working to ensure undocumented people within volunteer bases and the community know their rights in light of increased ICE presences.

She said NFCB has directed Spanish-language member stations to training on the use of red cards, small index cards created to assert one’s rights — regardless of citizenship status — and protect against potential constitutional violations by ICE agents. Numerous stations have adopted and distributed red cards among volunteers, she said.

One of these stations is WNHH 103.5 FM in New Haven, Conn. John Lugo, a station host and the co-founder and community organizing director of local immigration advocacy group Unidad Latina en Acción, has been leading the effort to hand out red cards within the station and in the community through his organization.

“ULA definitely has done the outreach,” said Norma Rodriguez-Reyes, the station’s chair and host of the bilingual program K Pasa. “They have literally gone door to door to pass these things out.”

Lugo said that while red cards are a start, immigrant and Latin American communities also need consistent, up-to-date information to keep pace with a rapidly evolving political climate.

“The red card is pretty limited,” Lugo said, adding that the community needs to know about “what’s going on at the national or federal level.”

Likewise, Radio KDNA 91.9 FM, a Spanish-language variety community station based in Granger, Wash., has relentlessly distributed red cards in the community since the spring, said Francisco Ríos, the station’s lead and news director.

“Many families have come to pick up one of these cards,” Ríos said. “At our community events that are held with other organizations, such as schools and community clinics, we’re also there distributing the red cards.”

Like WNHH, Ríos said KDNA is working to go beyond the red cards. He said providing the community with comprehensive information through “a series of messages that continue to educate and prepare families regarding all possible scenarios that may arise in the matter of migration” significantly adds to the objective of red cards.

“This is so families, in the case of an eventual deportation, ensure their children are well protected,” Ríos said.

Disseminating information

To keep communities informed about issues like ICE presence, Dael said that multiple Spanish-language stations are doing their best to continue serving communities while “staying under the radar of the current administration.”

She said many stations are keeping low profiles by collaborating with local community groups, such as immigration and refugee-serving organizations, to keep the community informed and to reduce the risk of being “seen as doing anything just themselves.”

“There’s a feeling that doing things collaboratively provides protection for some community radio stations,” Dael said.

Among these stations is KDNA. Ríos said the station receives five to 10 calls daily from community members seeking information about local immigrant rights groups or legal resources for recently detained loved ones.

KDNA has amped up relationships with organizations like the Northwest Immigrants Rights Project, a statewide immigrant advocacy nonprofit organization that provides migrants with legal services and community education. The station regularly features the organization on air to provide legal advice for navigating the current administration and obtaining legal status.

Similarly, WNHH airs La Voz del Migrante, a Spanish-language program focused on immigration-related news on the national, state and local levels, in partnership with Unidad Latina en Acción, which Lugo hosts one to two times a week. Lugo said the program regularly advises listeners on topics such as sorting legal documents and creating emergency plans in case of detention.

“Another topic that we talk on all the time with our communities is, don’t go to the court by yourself. Try to get help. Try to get connected with other groups,” Lugo said. “This is the time not to be alone. This is the time to build more community, to work together.”

KYMZ 99.9 FM Radio Sin Fronteras, a Spanish-language community station in Somerton, Ariz., is taking direction from its farmworker-oriented grassroots parent organization, Campesinos Sin Fronteras, to ensure its community stays informed about ICE operations.

Gregorio Perez, the station’s director of programming, said that although the station cannot tell listeners what to do or where to go, it relays information from Campesinos Sin Fronteras to give listeners the tools necessary to operate with caution.

“They’ll inform us, ‘You know what? There’s a campaign happening in such and such park at such and such place,’ so we just say, ‘Please friends, be careful in that area, you must take precautions,’” Perez said. “We try to disguise the message.”

Radio Bilingüe is working to ensure its network of 30 noncommercial stations and 75 affiliates has consistent and reliable access to information. Martínez-Saldaña said the network has recently brought on legal experts and immigration advocates to inform listeners of their rights and how to handle ICE encounters, hoping to ease “a little bit of that tension that exists.”

“We know that there is a lot of fear about the raids that have taken place,” Martínez-Saldaña said. “It’s experts that we bring on board that share, ‘Here are the things that you can do to protect yourself.’ We are the conduit of that information. The anxieties, we know, are in the community, and so we’re just trying to be a calm voice of reason.”

The station featured ​​Yanira Arias, program manager for the national immigrant community nonprofit Alianza Americas, on an episode of its Sin Fronteras program May 8 to discuss children with U.S. citizenship who had recently been deported along with their foreign-born parents. On the show, Arias analyzed the legality of ICE’s actions and advised undocumented families to get in contact with local organizations.

“This is an illegal action by the Donald Trump government,” Arias said on the show. “To the immigrants who find themselves in a similar situation, this is why it’s very important to reach out to community-based organizations to prepare family-emergency plans.”

Likewise, WNHH has brought on multiple immigration attorneys to speak to the community, Rodriguez-Reyes said. She said that the station also regularly brings local religious leaders on air, who offer reassurance and inspire hope in the Latin American community in the face of ICE raids. She added that faith-based organizations resonate deeply within the community.

“The Latino community has a very high percentage of people that attend church,” Rodriguez-Reyes said.

In addition to informing the community, Perez said KYMZ guides vulnerable community members to work with Campesinos Sin Fronteras for help with legal status issues. The organization supports community members with citizenship applications, renewing permanent residencies, initiating family-based petitions, and other immigration-related processes.

“What the organization does is invite people, if they’ve been living here, if they’re already residents, to become citizens so they can participate and vote,” Perez said. “The [administration’s] attacks are severe and brutal. There is fear within the community, not just here, but throughout the country.”

‘Leading through uncertainty’

Staffers at multilingual community radio stations say they have no option but to continue providing their communities with reliable immigration-related information.

Lugo said he’s often more outspoken on his show than hosts at other stations. He said that although his directness could invite retaliation from the federal government through ICE or the FCC, he’s willing to take the risk to keep listeners informed.

“It’s necessary because ICE is not announcing when they are in the community. They just show up whenever they want to,” Lugo said. “We have tens of thousands of our people who don’t have access to real information in real time, and I think community radio stations should play a role.”

Perez said community radio stations like KYMZ must continue their indispensable service during uncertain times, as many Spanish-speaking communities depend on stations for news and information. He said community members often call the station to confirm information heard elsewhere.

“It’s part of the culture to listen to the radio [in the] early morning for whatever situation, whether it’s for music, for everything,” Perez said. “In case of any emergency, people quickly tune in to the radio to see what’s going on. And if the announcer doesn’t mention anything, the same people call in to ask, ‘What’s going on here? Is it true that this or that happened?’”

He said KYMZ has recently found itself with fewer resources to fulfill its mission to keep farmworkers, immigrants and low-income families informed, as it previously received around 15% of its approximately $250,000 budget from CPB. The station has dismissed three employees: a manager, a director of programming and a Campesinos Sin Fronteras community health worker who served as a host.

Ríos said KDNA is in a similar boat. CPB funding made up approximately 20% to 30% of the station’s roughly $2.2 million annual budget, forcing it to suspend positions across the board, from producers and equipment maintenance to community outreach and grant writers.

He said that though the station’s workforce has dropped from 19 staff to just three in recent years, KDNA’s active volunteer network needs no further motivation to keep the station running smoothly.

“Here, the companions, all of us … have somebody who could be affected by the migration agenda,” Ríos said. “Therefore, they know and understand the needs and risks in our community because they are a part of it. … They understand the importance of every resource, every word we express on KDNA’s radio programs.”

In the meantime, Martinez-Saldaña said organizations like Radio Bilingüe have no choice but to ensure their communities remain informed.

“The alternative is you close the doors and go hide,” he said. “That’s not an option for us. Too many people depend on us, and so that’s our motivation. Our community needs us, but we need them as well.”

The interviews in this article with Francisco Ríos and Gregorio Perez were conducted in Spanish and translated into English by the reporter.

title: LSU nursing grad detained by ICE while work permit renewal pending | wwltv.com
description:
NEW ORLEANS — A young nurse who recently graduated from LSU remains detained at an ICE detention center in Basile, Louisiana, despite being in the middle of renewing her legal work authorization at the time of her arrest.
Vilma Palacios has been held at the ICE detention center in Basile for nearly six months, after being arrested by immigration agents on June 26.
She was a student ambassador and earned a peer mentor award," Matt Reese, Palacios' former nursing instructor said.
At the time of her detention, Palacios says she was actively renewing her work permit.
Just days before she was detained, Palacios passed her registered nursing certification exam.
text:
NEW ORLEANS — A young nurse who recently graduated from LSU remains detained at an ICE detention center in Basile, Louisiana, despite being in the middle of renewing her legal work authorization at the time of her arrest. Her case is like many others we've seen where people are somewhere in the middle — they have immigration paperwork or are somewhere in the middle.

Vilma Palacios has been held at the ICE detention center in Basile for nearly six months, after being arrested by immigration agents on June 26. She says the experience has been emotionally exhausting and something she would never wish on anyone.

“In here it has been a mix of emotions, a lot of ups and downs especially since the beginning I didn’t think I was going to be here for such a long time," Palacios told us over the phone from the detention center.

Palacios came to the United States from Honduras when she was 7 years old. After living in California, her family eventually settled in Louisiana, where she graduated from high school and later earned a nursing degree from LSU.

"I know her to be a high achiever academically. I know that she performed well in school and was a servant leader in school. She was a student ambassador and earned a peer mentor award," Matt Reese, Palacios' former nursing instructor said.

At the time of her detention, Palacios says she was actively renewing her work permit. Her previous authorization expired in March 2024, but she says she first applied for renewal in 2023. That process, she says, took nearly a year to receive a response. By the time she heard back, Palacios says there was confusion and someone handling her case believed it had been terminated. She submitted another renewal application and received confirmation in January of this year that it had been received.

RELATED: Responding to WWL report, Bovino says Border Patrol has detained 350 in Louisiana operation

“I had already sent an application to renew my work permit, and it was still in the process,” Palacios said.

Just days before she was detained, Palacios passed her registered nursing certification exam. She had already accepted a job offer at Touro and was preparing to begin her career.

Those who know her say her detention is devastating.

“I know the system needs there’s things that need to be fixed we need to protect our borders but at the same time you have someone like her," Rosemary Cortes, her aunt, said. "For us not to embrace someone like her, it’s heartbreaking. Here’s a perfect example of someone who has given so much to our community, her family, her friends, and we don’t want them here? That doesn’t make sense.”

Reese and Cortes are hoping she will be released soon. Reese says Palacios represents exactly the type of healthcare worker communities desperately need amid the nursing shortage.

“Vilma is ready to step up to the plate,” he said. “She is a compassionate and well-trained nurse she wants to give back to the community.”

But after nearly six months in detention, Palacios says the mental and emotional toll has become overwhelming.

“I’ve become very exhausted being in this place mentally, it's emotionally draining,” she said.

RELATED: Activists confronted agents making child porn arrest, mistaking them for ICE

Now, Palacios says she is considering self-deportation, even though she considers the United States her home.

“The laws aren't getting any better and they aren’t taking into consideration everything I’ve done in this country, the community ties I have, my family, everything. The amount of years I’ve been here, that I’ve tried to do everything right," she said. "They don’t take nothing into consideration and my plan is going back to Honduras."

Department of Homeland Security Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin sent WWL Louisiana a statement:

On June 26, 2025, DHS law enforcement arrested Vilma Nicol Palacios-Fuentes, an illegal alien from Honduras. She freely admitted to being in the U.S. illegally. She will receive full due process. To be clear, work authorization does not confer legal status.

We encourage all illegal aliens to take control of their departure with the CBP Home app. The American taxpayer is generously offering illegal aliens $1,000 and free flight home for the holidays.

title: ICE involved as feds violently detain Latino man in Mt. Washington - TribLIVE.com
description:
Neighbors living on Norton Street in Pittsburgh’s Mount Washington neighborhood woke Wednesday morning to sounds of screaming.
According to accounts given to Martinez and to TribLive, two unmarked vehicles sandwiched a white Tacoma pickup on the 400 block of Norton Street.
The truck — with an American flag decal in the back window — was still parked along Norton Street on Wednesday afternoon with a shattered driver’s side window.
Two witnesses told TribLive they recognized the man and his truck from the neighborhood but did not know him personally.
“Of note, Pittsburgh police is not apprised of ICE activity, such as federal administrative warrant service, in the City of Pittsburgh and does not assist ICE agents with such operations,” Cruz said.
text:
Neighbors living on Norton Street in Pittsburgh’s Mount Washington neighborhood woke Wednesday morning to sounds of screaming.

Witnesses told TribLive they watched federal agents hit, tackle, pepper spray and arrest a Latino man between 8 and 8:30 a.m.

“This is a new level of violence than we’ve seen in the city,” said Jaime Martinez, executive director of Frontline DIGNITY, a nonprofit that advocates for immigrants.

Martinez said he spoke with witnesses who saw the incident unfold.

According to accounts given to Martinez and to TribLive, two unmarked vehicles sandwiched a white Tacoma pickup on the 400 block of Norton Street.

They said agents broke the truck’s driver’s side window, pulled a man from the car and got into a physical altercation with him.

At least some of the agents on the scene were from U.S. Immigration & Customs Enforcement, according to Pittsburgh police.

Neighbors who saw the incident — including some who recorded it — said the agents punched the man and shoved him to the ground.

The truck — with an American flag decal in the back window — was still parked along Norton Street on Wednesday afternoon with a shattered driver’s side window.

Martinez said witnesses told him that agents pinned the man — who he could not identify — to the ground, even as he told them he could not breathe.

Pepper spray was deployed and seemed to get in the eyes of both the man being detained and at least one immigration agent.

One witness said he believed an ICE agent had been the one to pull out the pepper spray.

The man being detained was put in the back of an SUV, witnesses said, and not permitted to take water from a neighbor offering to help him clean out his eyes after the pepper spray.

The man was later moved to a van and driven away, witnesses said.

Two witnesses told TribLive they recognized the man and his truck from the neighborhood but did not know him personally.

As he was being led to the van, the man yelled in Spanish asking if he could take his phone.

Peter Blazak, 33, said he heard noises and saw flashing lights outside his home around 8 a.m.

“It looks like they were kind of wrestling with him,” Blazak said of the scene he saw unfold outside his home in what he described as a usually quiet street. “I heard a lot of screaming and shouting. It didn’t sound peaceful.”

Blazak said the man seemed to be kicking at the door or window of the van after agents had handcuffed him and put him in the vehicle.

A neighbor called Pittsburgh police, who were not initially on the scene when ICE detained the man.

Video obtained by TribLive shows several city police officers and at least one paramedic.

Martinez said he did not believe Pittsburgh police were cooperating with immigration officials. Witnesses said local police did not seem to assist ICE even after they arrived on scene.

Cara Cruz, a Pittsburgh public safety spokeswoman, said police responded to the 400 block of Norton Street around 8:25 a.m. “following multiple calls for an individual fighting with unknown law enforcement officers in the street.”

Medics arrived to evaluate “all parties,” including ICE agents and the man who was the “target of their operation,” Cruz said in a statement.

“Of note, Pittsburgh police is not apprised of ICE activity, such as federal administrative warrant service, in the City of Pittsburgh and does not assist ICE agents with such operations,” Cruz said. “Pittsburgh police officers respond to emergency calls for service in their jurisdiction.”

In January, Mayor Ed Gainey said Pittsburgh would not work with ICE.

“My administration will not work with ICE,” Gainey said during a PA Press Club event in Harrisburg. “We will do whatever’s necessary to make our city more welcoming. That’s what we’re built on.”

Jason Koontz, a spokesperson for ICE based in Philadelphia, said he was aware of the incident but could not immediately provide comment.

name: Human Rights
title: ACLU of Minnesota filing suit alleging ICE agents have violated constitutional rights
description:
The American Civil Liberties Union of Minnesota on Wednesday announced it is in the process of filing a lawsuit accusing federal agents of violating constitutional rights.
The state's ACLU chapter said it was filing the lawsuit on behalf of six community members.
ICE agents surged into the Twin Cities for an enhanced enforcement operation earlier this month at the direction of the Trump administration.
The agents have drawn the ire of both community members and Minneapolis city leaders.
ICE said agents "conducted themselves with the utmost professionalism" in responding to the crowd throwing snow and other objects.
text:
The American Civil Liberties Union of Minnesota on Wednesday announced it is in the process of filing a lawsuit accusing federal agents of violating constitutional rights.

The state's ACLU chapter said it was filing the lawsuit on behalf of six community members. In a release, the organization said agents from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, along with other agencies, have "engaged in a series of indiscriminate immigration raids in which masked federal officers in militarized gear brandish rifles and abduct community members from local businesses, streets, and homes."

The ACLU also alleges the agents have interfered with community members' right to free speech via "harassment, intimidation, force, and detention," such as by using rubber bullets and chemical irritants and arresting observers and protesters.

"This lawsuit asks the court — on behalf of these ordinary people who have come together courageously to stand up for the rights of all Americans — to halt ICE's attack on First and Fourth Amendment rights," the ACLU said.

ACLU staff attorney Alicia Granse said the suit asks the court to declare the agents' behavior unlawful and issue an order prohibiting them from carrying out that behavior. The ACLU will also seek a temporary restraining order while the court adjudicates the case.

One of the suit's plaintiffs, Susan Tincher, said she went to observe ICE activity in her Minneapolis neighborhood on Dec. 9, and within 15 seconds of her arrival, she was "on the ground in handcuffs."

"There was no warning, no explanation, no chance to comply," Tincher said.

Tincher said she was taken to a facility where she was "put in shackles" and "held for five hours" before being released.

"I did not obstruct. I did not disobey. I did not provoke violence," Tincher said. "I was on a public street and what followed was sudden, brutal and terrifying."

WCCO has reached out to the Department of Homeland Security for comment.

ICE agents surged into the Twin Cities for an enhanced enforcement operation earlier this month at the direction of the Trump administration. The Department of Homeland Security said agents have made more than 400 arrests since then.

The agents have drawn the ire of both community members and Minneapolis city leaders. On Tuesday, Police Chief Brian O'Hara criticized ICE after agents held a woman down and dragged her along the ground in south Minneapolis. Agents also deployed chemical irritants, and at one point, an agent used a Taser before yelling, "Who wants more?" to a gathered crowd.

"We have been training our officers for the last five years very, very intensely on de-escalation, but unfortunately that is … often not what we are seeing from other agencies in the city," O'Hara said.

ICE said agents "conducted themselves with the utmost professionalism" in responding to the crowd throwing snow and other objects.

O'Hara joined Mayor Jacob Frey and small business owners on Tuesday to discuss how ICE's presence is economically detrimental to the city.

ACLU of Minnesota Executive Director Deepinder Mayell said the organization will announce further legal action on Thursday.

"Since the launch of Operation Metro Surge, we have witnessed a remarkable string of unlawful activity targeting Minnesota communities and Minnesota values," Mayell said. "This affects us all."

Republican Rep. Tom Emmer said on X that "violent offenders are off the streets of Minnesota thanks to ICE and NO thanks to failed Governor Tim Walz and Mayor Jacob Frey."

text:
The day after a fellow judge in Hannah Dugan’s courthouse delivered damaging testimony against her, Milwaukee County Circuit Court Chief Judge Carl Ashley took the stand to lay out the draft policies for dealing with immigration enforcement.

Before Ashley’s testimony, Judge Kristela Cervera testified against Dugan on Tuesday. Ashley’s time on the witness stand wasn’t nearly as adversarial, and bolstered the defense case in significant respects.

Prosecutors claim that the emails and draft show Dugan exceeding her authority as a state court judge, but jurors also heard Ashley’s scathing criticism about how Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations can “significantly damage the integrity of the court system.”

“The presence of ICE agents can deter individuals, particularly immigrants and marginalized communities, from attending court hearings, seeking legal assistance, or reporting crimes,” Ashley wrote in a press release on April 6. “This undermines the fundamental right to access the courts and seek legal remedies.”

The press release lists three harms to the state judiciary: “Chilling Effect on Access to Justice,” “Erosion of Trust in the Judicial System,” and “Confusion over Legal Protections.”

“When individuals perceive courthouses as unsafe due to the fear of detention, trust in the judicial system erodes,” Ashley wrote. “This can lead to a reluctance to engage with law enforcement, legal representation, and the courts, ultimately hindering the administration of justice.”

Dugan’s lead attorney Steven Biskupic posed a series of questions to the chief judge about the language.

Asked whether he wanted the public and other judges to know his views, Ashley replied: “I did.”

“Is everything you wrote something you believed?” Biskupic asked.

“Yes,” he affirmed.

Later that month, a six-member team went to the 6th floor hallway of Milwaukee County Circuit Court to arrest Eduardo Flores-Ruiz, a defendant before Judge Dugan. Prosecutors argue that Ashley’s guidance should have informed Dugan that the administrative warrant that they had for Flores-Ruiz’s arrest was sufficient, and they had full authority to arrest the defendant in public areas.

Asked about his view of the law, Ashley replied: “I don’t believe that I was able to stop anything in a public hallway.”

On cross-examination, however, Biskupic showed that Ashley specifically struck language used by San Francisco’s model explicitly allowing hallway arrest.

The language that Ashley declined to use for Milwaukee County Circuit Court read: “Immigration enforcement agents are allowed to conduct their operations in the Court’s Public Areas.”

Dugan is charged with felony obstruction and concealing an individual facing arrest.
